comment:
Before suggesting a GMS game please supply additional information about the game: GMS version, bytecode and YYC usage. To check your suggestion you can open the *data.win* or *game.unx* file with the Bleeding Edge version of [UnderTaleModTool](https://github.com/UnderminersTeam/UndertaleModTool). You will find the version and bytecode at the top of the program, above the toolbar. If the game uses YYC, you will see a pop-up warning.

comment:
OpenGL & SDL 1.2 Requirements
https://packages.debian.org/stable/games/foobillardplus

Compiles fine after forcing trough the automake system.

- Replace PKG_CHECK_MODULES with direct freetype-config checks
- Add explicit header check for ft2build.h
- Improve error messages for missing Freetype2
- Remove dependency on pkg-config for Freetype2 detection
- Set FREETYPE_CFLAGS and FREETYPE_LIBS using freetype-config

Starts and runs the music but the screen stays black.
No noteworthy error messages.

Status:

- Game initializes and reaches main loop, audio works, but screen remains black
- No obvious errors in log, suggesting subtle rendering pipeline issue
- Next steps: Add detailed OpenGL error checking, implement basic triangle render test
- Check SDL/OpenGL interaction, verify game loop and buffer swapping
title: FooBillard++

comment:
Well, where to begin?  I might find it easier to quote verbatim from the GitHub page itself...

*start quotation*

A project to statically recompile DOS and Windows game executables to create Windows or Linux (x86 or arm) versions of the games.

Following DOS games are supported:

    Albion
    X-Com: UFO Defense (UFO: Enemy Unknown)
    X-Com: Terror from the Deep
    Warcraft: Orcs & Humans

Following Windows games are supported:

    Septerra Core: Legacy of the Creator
    Battle Isle 3: Shadow of the Emperor (Battle Isle 2220: Shadow of the Emperor)

The source code is released with MIT license (except libraries, etc. by other people, which have their own license). For the purpose of using the code in GPL projects, the source code is also released with GPLv2 or later and LGPLv2.1 or later.

*end quotation*

Above screenshot is of Albion, one of the supported titles.  For what it's worth I remember playing the SR ports of this game and Warcraft on my old GP2X Wiz many a moon ago. :)

This isn't really an "anything goes" "emulator" just to be precise - each individual game has to have support programmed for it, and seperate replacement binaries are released for each one.  Both 32-bit and 64-bit binaries are available, but the 64-bit ones (that is, aarch64 and x86_64) are considered EXPERIMENTAL (in big scary letters).  Also, there are different options for MIDI playback support that use different libraries, so there may or may not be limits on what ones you're willing to support, I suppose?

All the supported games so far appear to be the RPG/strategic "point-and-click" titles of the 90s - whether these would be mostly playable on many of the PM-supported devices I wouldn't know, but I have a hunch that analog sticks at the very least will be recommended.

I figured a single page for this project would be sufficient enough rather than create a page for each supported game and link to the same Github page for all of them.  Still, if you would prefer each game to be listed seperately, feel free to let me know.

Whew, think I said enough for this one!
title: SR (Static Recompiler)

Initial Problem:
The game was crashing when trying to open the main menu (when pressing Escape). This was likely due to issues with font loading or rendering.
Current Status:

The game now starts without crashing.
The main menu appears to be functional (you can click "New Game").
However, you cannot interact with the chess pieces to move them.

Root Cause (Suspected):
The font loading issue seems to have been resolved by correctly defining the FONTS_DIR and ensuring the font was loaded properly. This fixed the immediate crash.
Current Issue:
The inability to move pieces suggests there might be a problem with:

Event handling for mouse interactions with the game board
Game state management after starting a new game
Possible threading issues related to AI player thinking or game logic

Next Steps:

Analyze the debug output from the event handling system to see if mouse events are being properly recognized on the game board.
Verify that the game state is correctly initialized after starting a new game.
Check if there are any issues with the AI thinking thread that might be blocking user input.
Attachment file type: archive
brutalchess.zip
20.28 MB
I'm done with it, 5 hours and no longer motivated to do further stuff
At least the main menu works now
and you can let the cpus play against each other

The source code for this early iD Software/Softdisk game was released a decade ago but to my knowledge no public builds of this SDL port were made available.  I wonder if it's still fairly portable?

There were a couple of offshoots made from the source code in the form of:

comment:
Recently learned about this fork of ECWolf when I read that it was possible to run the Macintosh version of Wolf3D through a port, and couldn't get ECWolf to run it even on DRD Team's most recent nightly build (2024-05-24) so researched on it.

There's a whole mod category dedicated to making mods that specifically use the Mac version via an extracted MacBinary file, and Laz Rojas' scenarios can also be loaded as addons this way.  This Mac support is supposed to be part of the future ECWolf 2.0 but that's still an undetermined distance away, so this seems like the next best option.

There's also an "lzwolf-sdl2" page on Github: https://github.com/madmodder123/lzwolf-sdl2 , since I'm not sure if the version on Bitbucket still uses SDL1.  It was last updated on 2020-08-10, whereas the Bitbucket repository was last updated on 2022-12-26.

This appears to be a fan-made alternative port of Hydra Castle Labyrinth by JeffRuLz.  While looking identical to the original, it does make some subtle changes to the overall experience.  Inexplicably, nobody seems to have made a full list of the actual changes, so I can only report on the ones I've seen myself, namely:

- When standing in front of a dungeon door, a popup box conveniently showing the name of the dungeon in question appears.  This is useful for knowing which doors go with which keys.
- The BGM will now resume from where it left off after finishing playing a jingle, instead of starting over from the beginning.
- Collision detection seems to have been tweaked here and there.  For instance, whereas in OG HCL you could comfortably whack a wall cannon above you with your sword without having to physically jump to it, you can't in this one.

That's all I remember so far.  Maybe you're supposed to find all the different little changes yourself or something? XD
title: OpenHCL

As for the second point, PortMaster already has games running on EDuke32? So I don't quite get the issue.

comment:
OpenFMV is an open-source full-motion video game engine intended for use with a bunch of games by Wales Interactive, all of the FMV kind.  At this stage however, only one of them - Late Shift - is fully supported, playable and completable.

This is a rather interesting case.  The original game as distributed on Steam and GOG runs on Unity, but this engine bypasses that little issue by handling all of the logic, menu and video assets itself (albeit after a lengthy conversion process as detailed on the Github page - that said, it significantly reduces the overall size, from the Unity original's ~8GB down to just ~2GB!).

While it's presently designed for PS Vita, hopefully it wouldn't be too difficult to translate it for other ARM handhelds...

Cebion: Rewriting Vita Apps to Linux is out of our scope.
title: OpenFMV / Late Shift

comment:
The Rednukem engine is capable of running Duke Nukem 64 via a ROM dump file of the original game. I have attempted to experiment with replacing files in the Rednukem version already available for Duke Nukem 3D, but I can't seem to be able to get it to run (complains about the ROM file "not being found" despite being placed in the correct and references properly in the config file.)

If it's at all possible to get this running on compatible devices, it would be a good addition to the existing Rednukem-based port lineup.

Slayer366: Unfortunately, while RedNukem does indeed support running the contents of the Duke64 ROM natively, it needs OpenGL to satisfy the N64 aesthetic and is requried.  What's more is this could be possible via Polymost or Polymer (OpenGL modes for Eduke based source ports) if it's implemented with GLES, but even EDuke32 suffers from not having GLES support for these modes and the one or two custom builds that do only seem to work on a Raspberry Pi.
title: Duke Nukem 64 (Rednukem)

Mouse: Cursor/Move Camera
LMB: Select/Mark Safe/Clear Mark
RMB: Cancel/Mark Unsafe/Clear Mark

Esc: Main Menu/Close current Menu
Arrow Keys/WASD: Move camera/Move player in level select area
E: Toggle Info Overlay
Space/Enter: Interact with NPC in level select area in Campaign mode
C - Start unit Move
X - Start unit Action
F - Modify selected Unit
Q - End turn
Alt+Enter: Toggle Fullscreen
F12: Save Screenshot

There's also an itchi.io page: https://onehundredthousand.itch.io/katjas-abyss-tactics

comment:
I feel this would be an excellent inclusion just for mod-supported splitscreen.

It is an rather ancient engine, and you can likely just use gl4es (OpenGL 1.3 min) and SDL12-compat or SDL2 to get it going.

*ideal* deps according to its compiling readme:
- SDL2
- SDL2 mixer
- Opengl 1.3+ (covered by ES)
- zlib
- libzip
- dlopen
- GCC 3.3+ or Clang 3.8+

comment:
GameMaker 2 game released in 2023. Has a variety of older demos available (latest being the Eggplant Build in 2022, closest demo to release build and features a lot of things shown in the final release)

Uses Bytecode and GMS 2022.9.0.0

Game can be intensive on low end hardware; can likely boost performance by disabling certain unneeded elements (e.g. level backgrounds)

There are unofficial Android APKs that exist and are functional as the full game, though they tend to be multiple versions behind.

Officially, the game is Windows-only. Runs on Linux through Proton. 

Looking at internal assets, it uses shaders that utilise GLSL_ES. Unsure if this means it's more compatible or not, so GL4ES may be needed?

comment:
Originally released in 1995 as a DOS game, it was decompiled many moons ago by John Jordan (jjffe), which allowed various ports that included higher end graphics, modernized rending engine support as well as releases across different operating systems including Linux. 

In 1999, Frontier Developments, the company behind the game, made the game available for free on their website, effectively releasing it as freeware. However, this does not mean the game is open-source or that the underlying code is available for modification or redistribution under a more permissive license like GPL or MIT.

So, while you can legally download and play Frontier: First Encounters for free, the game itself remains under copyright, and Frontier Developments retains the rights to the game.
title: Frontier: First Encounters

comment:
Rockbot is an open-source, SDL library based, game engine to replicate old style games like Megaman. It is a homebrew platformer made in the spirit of Capcom’s classic Megaman (Rockman in Japan) game series (1-6 and 9-10), that have original storyline and graphics, besides an editor where the user can edit their own stage and enemies. 

This has been around for quite a long time now.  It's seen many console and handheld ports in various years and state of completion/production for the likes of PSP, PS2, Wii, NDS, (Open)Dingux, OpenPandora, Raspberry Pi, and PocketGo (on top of the standard Windows and Linux versions).

Originally, it resembled Megaman more closely in terms of certain art, animations, startup sequences and overall style.  But in 2019 there was apparently a kerfuffle with Google over the Android port that had been released to Google Play, where other people accused it of copying Megaman too much (even though the developer stressed on his blog that very few elements of the game were borrowed from Megaman at the time) - note that there's nothing to suggest that Capcom themselves ever so much as said a word about the project, let alone complain about it.  So it got pulled from the app store, and the developer decided (in order to get it back on there and rechristen it "RockDroid") to significantly change much of the game to make it less "Megaman-like", mainly in the artwork (which adopted a new 'chibi' style), sprites and startup animations (the music meanwhile was always "original", or at least borrowed from Modland et al).  The old versions of the project are still available for download so you can see how much the game got changed over the years for yourself.  (The chosen screenshot - according to the URL, is from v1.1.0 back in 2015.  It's pretty difficult to find many screenshots of the game that are big enough to display clearly and don't have a window box surrounding the picture.)

Also, a little warning regarding the differing 'current' versions available - while there appear to be builds marked "1.x" and "2.x" being released together, these actually relate to different games as opposed to the same one.  "2.x" is more of a "Rockbot 2" followup, with different levels and enemies, with "1.x" being commonly known as "Rockbot 1".

No specific license info could be found on the project's Github page, so I'm going to assume it's of the "mixed" kind.

https://github.com/protoman/rockbot
title: Rockbot

comment:
m8c is a client for Dirtywave M8 tracker's headless mode. It requires a Teensy 4.1 running M8 Headless, or a Dirtywave M8 connected via USB to run. It routes audio from the M8 to the output of your device and uses serial to communicate the controls and graphics to and from the M8. I have made a modified version of  arkos which only runs m8c (https://youtu.be/VxFdom2PnwA). 
 
Upon first boot it reads and write a config.ini file in ~/.local/share/m8c
in order for the sound to work, audio_enabled has to be set to true.
It also looks for gamecontrollerdb.txt. First in the same folder as the config file, if there is none present in /usr/bin/.
The default controls on my r36s seem fine.
title: m8c

comment:
Some tech-savvy players also discovered that the PC version packaged the HashLink VM. Early on, Linux users had to manually update a HashLink module (fmt.hdll) to get the game running due to a library mismatch​.
​
This revealed that Dead Cells on Linux shipped with HashLink and relied on system libraries like SDL2 and OpenAL, which needed to be present or correctly versioned. Those trying to run the game on atypical setups (like without Steam) learned they could run the deadcells.hl bytecode with the HashLink interpreter, though the normal distribution includes an executable to handle this transparently.

The Hashlink interpreter is open source and available here:
https://heaps.io/documentation/hello-hashlink.html
however note that the jit compiler outputs x86_64 assembly instructions.

comment:
Well this was a pleasant surprise.  It appears the source code for Unreal 1 had been available for some years now judging by the existence of this GitHub page: https://github.com/RedPandaProjects/UnrealEngine

Well, fast forward to today and a visit to VitaDB revealed a PS Vita port.  Which led me to the GitHub page for UE1 as linked.  The port exists for Windows, Linux and Vita, and the Linux version currently supports both X86 and ARM32.  Nothing about a 64-bit version so far, but it's probably early days.  So most handhelds should be able to (hopefully) support this, but it looks like the TeaSpooners are screwed. :\

Currently supported are v200 of the original retail game (which after some testing can confirm to be literally any non-OEM version of the OG U1 from '98) and the v205 demo (also known as Unreal Special Edition).  *Not* currently supported are any OEM edition of U1, any version of Return to Na Pali, and Unreal Gold.  Given that the Unreal series was removed from all digital storefronts yet Epic recently gave OldUnreal.com their blessing to make installers for U1 and UT99 that download the original ISO images from Archive.org and extract the data, apply the newest community patches et al, *and* have started acknowledging this on their own website (https://www.epicgames.com/unrealtournament) this seems like jolly good timing. :)  Question: can the content still be considered "Commercial" when it's no longer being sold anywhere and the company themselves is like "sure, go ahead and use free ISOs for your installers"?

Note: I wasn't too sure whether to select "Unreal" for the Engine part.  I mean, it's literally Unreal, but I assume that option is mainly intended for modern-day UE like 4 or 5 or whatever the commonly used version is.  So I just picked "Other/Unknown" until somebody can clarify things. :)
title: UE1
